title: The Citi Foundation, Citi Panama and Centro Nacional De Competitividad Reward Microenterprise in Panama
summary: Panama City - The Citi Foundation, in collaboration with Citi Panama and Centro Nacional de Competitividad (CNC), named the winners of Panama's sixth annual Microentrepreneurship Awards (PREMIC 2013), an initiative designed to promote microentrepreneurship in the country.
tag-1: The Citi Foundation, Citi Panama and Centro Nacional De Competitividad Reward Microenterprise in Panama
tag-3: Panama City – The Citi Foundation, in collaboration with Citi Panama and Centro Nacional de Competitividad (CNC), named the winners of Panama's sixth annual Microentrepreneurship Awards (PREMIC 2013), an initiative designed to promote microentrepreneurship in the country.
tag-4: The Citi Foundation presents the awards in 32 countries around the world – 13 of them in Latin America – to raise awareness of the impact and importance of microfinance and to acknowledge the extraordinary contributions of microenterprise in promoting development and economic sustainability, not only for the families of microentrepreneurs but also for the communities where they operate.
tag-5: "At the global level, the project seeks to strengthen the entrepreneurial spirit in impoverished communities around the world and their ability to contribute to reaching the United Nations' Millennium Challenge Goals," Citi Panama General Manager Raymond Gatcliffe noted.
tag-6: This year the program distributed a total of B/.23,000.00 in prize money in three categories: Commerce, Industry and Services, along with special mentions for rural enterprises, creativity and innovation, and community impact, as well as a top prize for Microentrepreneur of the Year.
tag-7: Seventy-one microenterprises from around the country submitted their candidacy, facilitated by Citi's strategic partnership with the CNC and the valuable participation of microfinance institutions such as Banco Delta, Banco G&T Continental, Cooperativa Juan XXIII, Microserfin, Rapi Prestamos, Financia Credit and Procaja. The entries were reviewed by an experienced judging committee, which named two winners in each category as well as 10 finalists.
tag-8: Commerce First prize: Arquimedes Peralta, aquaculture, nominated by Procaja. Second prize: Nathaniel García Torres, handcrafts, nominated by Microserfin.
tag-9: Industry First prize: José Alcides Pérez, biodegradable chemicals, nominated by Microserfin. Second prize: Dioris Moreno, of Hermanos Moreno ebony workshop, nominated by Banco Delta.
tag-10: Services First prize: Adelaida Salinas, of San Judas Tadeo laundromat, nominated by Banco Delta. Second prize: Apolonia Rodríguez, of Aime beauty parlor, nominated by Banco G & T Continental.
tag-11: Creativity and Innovation First prize: Manuel Dolores Caro, of Asociación para el Desarrollo de Empleo, nominated by Banco Delta. Second prize: Armando Castillo, of Empresa Antena Circulares, nominated by Banco Delta.
tag-12: Rural Enterprise First prize: Ferdinand Vernaza, of Forestal Santa Fe, nominated by Procaja. Second prize: Maria del C. Concepción, of Fonda Yosselyn, nominated by Banco Delta.
tag-13: The top prize, for Microentrepreneur of the Year, went to Alcides Pérez, a resident of Chiriquí province, nominated by Microserfin, which has helped him grow his biodegradable chemicals business to include water heaters for cleaning the pipes at dairy farms and pasteurization equipment for eradicating disease-causing bacteria.
tag-14: The recipient of the special award for Community Impact was Manuel Caro, who has received support from Banco Delta in Santa Ana, Panama City to create the Asociación para el Desarrollo de Empleo (Job Development Association), which trains young people in socially vulnerable situations in the skills and aptitudes they need to join the labor market. The association's work is supported by candy sales.
tag-15: For the first time, this year's awards also included a special recognition for the most innovative microfinance institution. Asociación para el Desarrollo de las Cajas Rurales (Procaja) won for its Financial Education program, which reaches even the most remote parts of the country through radio broadcasts. "Initiatives such as the Microentrepreneurship Awards recognize the effort and creativity small business owners show every day," remarked the CNC's General Director, Dr. Nicolás Ardito Barletta. "The CNC is proud to be part of this project."
tag-16: Citi Citi, the leading global bank, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.

tag-18: The Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of individuals and families, particularly those in need, in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, Youth Education and Livelihoods, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance and Enterprise Development to support environmental programs and innovations. Additional information can be found at www.citifoundation.com.
tag-19: Citi Panama Citi Panama is a leading provider of financial services in Panama, with 108 years of uninterrupted operations in the country. It offers individuals, corporations, governments and institutions a wide range of financial products and services in the areas of corporate, retail and investment banking.
tag-20: Centro Nacional de Competitividad (CNC) Centro Nacional de Competitividad (CNC) is a non-profit organization that collaborates closely with local and international partners in the public and private sectors to implement programs that support microentrepreneurship through financial support and training.
